elements.content: This communication describes an infinite 1D ribbon metal–organic framework (MOF) that crystallizes to produce large channels (13.4 × 17.5 Å) and exhibits strong aggregation enhanced fluorescence emission. The network is composed of tetrapyridine tetraphenylethene molecules coordinating to ZnCl2 nodes. When activated, the network exhibits enhanced turn-on fluorescence in response to methyl-substituted volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and quenching in response to nitro-substituted VOCs. This MOF shows potential as a valuable sensor due to its high surface area, highly fluorescent TPE moiety, and significant response to VOCs.
elements.clean_text: This communication describes an infinite 1D ribbon metal-organic framework (MOF) that crystallizes to produce large channels (13.4 × 17.5 Å) and exhibits strong aggregation enhanced fluorescence emission. The network is composed of tetrapyridine tetraphenylethene molecules coordinating to ZnCl2 nodes. When activated, the network exhibits enhanced turn-on fluorescence in response to methyl-substituted volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and quenching in response to nitro-substituted VOCs. This MOF shows potential as a valuable sensor due to its high surface area, highly fluorescent TPE moiety, and significant response to VOCs.

elements.content:
An infinite 1D ribbon MOF based on Zn-Py-TPE shows potential as a valuable sensor due to its high surface area, highly fluorescent TPE moeity, and its powerful response to VOCs.

Porous metal–organic frameworks (PMOFs) are a subset of inorganic–organic hybrid solid materials. They are constructed by rational linking of functionalized organic molecules with inorganic nodes. They have been the subject of intense and increasing research due to their potential use in a wide variety of applications, including gas storage and separation, catalysis, and proton conduction. Photoluminescent PMOFs have proven potential as chemical sensors as they possess strong, controllable fluorescence and large surface areas with tunable pore sizes. They have been used previously as sensors for gases, ions, pesticides, and explosives. Most known PMOF sensors act in a “turn-off” fashion where the fluorescence of the system is reduced as analyte is introduced, whereas very few known networks are capable of demonstrating both “turn-on” and “turn-off” behavior.
elements.clean_text:
An infinite 1D ribbon MOF based on Zn-Py-TPE shows potential as a valuable sensor due to its high surface area, highly fluorescent TPE moeity, and its powerful response to VOCs.

Porous metal-organic frameworks (PMOFs) are a subset of inorganic-organic hybrid solid materials. They are constructed by rational linking of functionalized organic molecules with inorganic nodes. They have been the subject of intense and increasing research due to their potential use in a wide variety of applications, including gas storage and separation, catalysis, and proton conduction. Photoluminescent PMOFs have proven potential as chemical sensors as they possess strong, controllable fluorescence and large surface areas with tunable pore sizes. They have been used previously as sensors for gases, ions, pesticides, and explosives. Most known PMOF sensors act in a "turn-off" fashion where the fluorescence of the system is reduced as analyte is introduced, whereas very few known networks are capable of demonstrating both "turn-on" and "turn-off" behavior.

elements.content: The drawback of using fluorescence based sensing is aggregation-induced quenching in which the emissive properties of the fluorophore are weakened in the solid state and when it is present in high concentrations. For this reason, tetraphenylethene (TPE) was chosen as a fluorophore as it exhibits aggregation enhanced emission (AIE). In solution, the fluorophore is nonemissive as the excited state is able to undergo nonradiative decay through intramolecular motion. However, once aggregated, either in the solid state or in high concentration, this pathway is no longer available. Thus, the chromophore begins to exhibit strong fluorescence. TPE is known to possess this property as a result of the restricted rotation and motion of its central phenyl groups. Additionally, this effect can act as a turn-on sensor by further restricting the movement of the phenyl groups by “fixing” the orientation and spacing of the TPE in a MOF, which can activate fluorescence and also control the environment of the chromophore.
elements.clean_text: The drawback of using fluorescence based sensing is aggregation-induced quenching in which the emissive properties of the fluorophore are weakened in the solid state and when it is present in high concentrations. For this reason, tetraphenylethene (TPE) was chosen as a fluorophore as it exhibits aggregation enhanced emission (AIE). In solution, the fluorophore is nonemissive as the excited state is able to undergo nonradiative decay through intramolecular motion. However, once aggregated, either in the solid state or in high concentration, this pathway is no longer available. Thus, the chromophore begins to exhibit strong fluorescence. TPE is known to possess this property as a result of the restricted rotation and motion of its central phenyl groups. Additionally, this effect can act as a turn-on sensor by further restricting the movement of the phenyl groups by "fixing" the orientation and spacing of the TPE in a MOF, which can activate fluorescence and also control the environment of the chromophore.

elements.content: Many volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are toxic compounds that have significant vapor pressures at room temperature. By law, the emission of anthropogenic VOCs must be monitored, and as such, detection of VOCs is vital. PMOFs have previously demonstrated potential as fluorescent molecular sensors for VOCs, and TPE-based networks are a focal point of this research. In this work, methyl- and nitro- substituted benzenes have been used as model compounds. Of particular interest is 2,4-dinitrotoluene (DNT), a predictable byproduct in the manufacture of 2,4,6 trinitrotoluene (TNT). The relatively high vapor pressure of DNT means that it is often used as an indicator for the presence of nitro-aromatic explosives.
elements.clean_text: Many volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are toxic compounds that have significant vapor pressures at room temperature. By law, the emission of anthropogenic VOCs must be monitored, and as such, detection of VOCs is vital. PMOFs have previously demonstrated potential as fluorescent molecular sensors for VOCs, and TPE-based networks are a focal point of this research. In this work, methyl- and nitro- substituted benzenes have been used as model compounds. Of particular interest is 2,4-dinitrotoluene (DNT), a predictable byproduct in the manufacture of 2,4,6 trinitrotoluene (TNT). The relatively high vapor pressure of DNT means that it is often used as an indicator for the presence of nitro-aromatic explosives.

elements.content: Recently, a number of TPE-based sensors for VOCs have been synthesized. These systems exploit the turn-on fluorescence that occurs when the TPE derivative aggregates. However, these networks have focused on a carboxylic based ligand, namely, tetracarboxy-tetraphenylethene. In this communication, we present a network with superior properties utilizing a pyridyl based ligand, tetrapyridine-tetraphenylethene (Py-TPE) (), that is more thermally stable, water-stable, and more sensitive. The network can be regenerated and exhibited enhanced turn-on fluorescence in response volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and quenching in response to nitro-substituted VOCs.
elements.clean_text: Recently, a number of TPE-based sensors for VOCs have been synthesized. These systems exploit the turn-on fluorescence that occurs when the TPE derivative aggregates. However, these networks have focused on a carboxylic based ligand, namely, tetracarboxy-tetraphenylethene. In this communication, we present a network with superior properties utilizing a pyridyl based ligand, tetrapyridine-tetraphenylethene (Py-TPE) (), that is more thermally stable, water-stable, and more sensitive. The network can be regenerated and exhibited enhanced turn-on fluorescence in response volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and quenching in response to nitro-substituted VOCs.

elements.content: Structure of tetrapyridine-tetraphenylethene (Py-TPE) ligand.
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of tetrapyridine-tetraphenylethene (Py-TPE) ligand.

elements.content: The ligand Py-TPE (10 mg, 0.0156 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of 3:1 tetrachloroethene (TCE)/methanol, which then had a methanolic solution of zinc chloride (10 mL, 8.7 mg, 0.64 mmol) layered on top. Upon standing for several days, yellow plate-like crystals of (Zn2Cl4Py-TPE)·4­(TCE) (1) (69% yield) formed, which were characterized by elemental analysis: Calcd for (Zn2Cl4Py-TPE) after removal of solvent is C, 60.49; N, 6.17%; H, 3.53. Found C, 60.78; N, 6.14; H, 3.59%. Its thermal stability was examined by thermogravimetric (TGA) analysis and its structure determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis.
elements.clean_text: The ligand Py-TPE (10 mg, 0.0156 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of 3:1 tetrachloroethene (TCE)/methanol, which then had a methanolic solution of zinc chloride (10 mL, 8.7 mg, 0.64 mmol) layered on top. Upon standing for several days, yellow plate-like crystals of (Zn2Cl4Py-TPE)⋅4(TCE) (1) (69% yield) formed, which were characterized by elemental analysis: Calcd for (Zn2Cl4Py-TPE) after removal of solvent is C, 60.49; N, 6.17%; H, 3.53. Found C, 60.78; N, 6.14; H, 3.59%. Its thermal stability was examined by thermogravimetric (TGA) analysis and its structure determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 1 crystallizes in the C1 space group, and the data is summarized in . The fundamental asymmetric group contains one Py-TPE molecule, one ZnII cation, and two coordinated chloride ions. As shown in , each pyridine group coordinates to a single ZnII, and each ZnII cation coordinates to two pyridine groups and two chlorides with tetrahedral stereochemistry. This creates an infinite 1D ribbon composed of metal-pyridine secondary building units (SBUs), running along the b axis, as seen in b,c. The Zn–N and Zn–Cl distances are in the range of 2.00–2.29 and 2.20–2.21 Å, respectively, and are typical of such bonds. The N–Zn–N angles are 105.3° and the Cl–Zn–Cl angles are 125.8° creating a slightly distorted tetrahedral stereochemistry about the ZnII ions. The layers consist of pairs of metal ions positioned adjacent to each other, separated by 6.216 Å via their respective chloride ions (see Supporting Information, Figure S3.). The adjacent chlorides exhibit similar behavior to that seen in other octahedral systems, with the ions positioned 3.73 Å away from the central ethene bond of the Py-TPE in the next layer. The chlorides are situated over the ethene center of adjacent Py-TPE molecules along the a axis. This compares to 3.40 Å in similar systems.

This creates an infinite 1D ribbon composed of metal-pyridine secondary building units (SBUs), running along the b axis, as seen in b,c. The Zn-N and Zn-Cl distances are in the range of 2.00-2.29 and 2.20-2.21 Å, respectively, and are typical of such bonds. The N-Zn-N angles are 105.3° and the Cl-Zn-Cl angles are 125.8° creating a slightly distorted tetrahedral stereochemistry about the ZnII ions. The layers consist of pairs of metal ions positioned adjacent to each other, separated by 6.216 Å via their respective chloride ions (see Supporting Information, Figure S3.). The adjacent chlorides exhibit similar behavior to that seen in other octahedral systems, with the ions positioned 3.73 Å away from the central ethene bond of the Py-TPE in the next layer. The chlorides are situated over the ethene center of adjacent Py-TPE molecules along the a axis. This compares to 3.40 Å in similar systems.

Details of Crystal Data and Structure Refinement Parameters of [(ZnCl<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub> Py-TPE] <bold>1</bold> <xref rid="tbl1-fn1"></xref> empirical formula C31H24Cl2ZnN2 Mr 560.79 crystal size 0.067 × 0.085 × 0.210 crystal color clear yellow crystal system monoclinic space group C2/m T (K) 200(1) a (Å) 18.902(3) b (Å) 17.472(3) c (Å) 13.206(2) α (deg) 90 β (deg) 115.736(3) γ (deg) 90 volume (Å3) 3928.7(10) Z 4 D calc (g cm–3) 0.948 μ (mm–1) 0.777 2θmax (deg) 52.88 data collected 21554 refined parameters/restraints 4154/170 goodness of fit on F 2 0.877 R1 [I > 2σ(I)] 0.0529 wR2 (all data) 0.1566

Note that the occluded TCE molecules were masked using SQUEEZE and so are not represented in this table (CCDC: 1458042).

In contrast to the free Py-TPE ligand, which decomposes at temperatures above 120 °C, compound 1 demonstrated thermal stability up to 450 °C. The TGA performed in an inert atmosphere (N2) shows two distinct losses. First, at 150 °C, there is a 40% weight-loss that corresponds to TCE expulsion beyond which the network remains stable until 450 °C, after which it begins to decay and evolve organic decomposition products. Upon completion of the TGA at 750 °C, 35% of the mass remains, which can be attributed to the remaining metal oxide and decomposition products. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis demonstrated the resilience of the structure since even after five regeneration cycles (150 °C under vacuum for 3 h), the PXRD remained unchanged (see Supporting Information Figure S6). b,c shows the creation of rhomboid shaped voids (13.4 × 17.5 Å) within the structure, which are occupied by TCE molecules that have been incorporated during the synthesis. This was confirmed via GC–MS and FTIR analysis of the volatiles released during the TGA after the loss of 10% of the total mass. Additionally, the evacuated network was analyzed via TGA. It demonstrated the expected behavior; remaining stable until the pyrolysis of the ligand at 500 °C (see Supporting Information Figure S12).

Upon completion of the TGA at 750 °C, 35% of the mass remains, which can be attributed to the remaining metal oxide and decomposition products. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis demonstrated the resilience of the structure since even after five regeneration cycles (150 °C under vacuum for 3 h), the PXRD remained unchanged (see Supporting Information Figure S6). b,c shows the creation of rhomboid shaped voids (13.4 × 17.5 Å) within the structure, which are occupied by TCE molecules that have been incorporated during the synthesis. This was confirmed via GC-MS and FTIR analysis of the volatiles released during the TGA after the loss of 10% of the total mass. Additionally, the evacuated network was analyzed via TGA. It demonstrated the expected behavior; remaining stable until the pyrolysis of the ligand at 500 °C (see Supporting Information Figure S12).

elements.content: Like most TPE derivatives, the Py-TPE ligand exhibits aggregation induced emission (AIE) behavior in the solid and aggregated states. In these states, the rotation of the phenyl rings is limited, and therefore, fluorescence is enhanced. The strong emission of the ligand ensures the network [ZnCl2Py-TPE·4­(TCE)] (1) is also highly luminescent in the solid-state at room temperature. The fluorescence emission maxima of ligand and network 1 are 515 and 530 nm (λex = 340 nm), respectively, with the network 1 emission being red-shifted compared to the ligand emission, independent of the excitation wavelength.
elements.clean_text: Like most TPE derivatives, the Py-TPE ligand exhibits aggregation induced emission (AIE) behavior in the solid and aggregated states. In these states, the rotation of the phenyl rings is limited, and therefore, fluorescence is enhanced. The strong emission of the ligand ensures the network [ZnCl2Py-TPE⋅4(TCE)] (1) is also highly luminescent in the solid-state at room temperature. The fluorescence emission maxima of ligand and network 1 are 515 and 530 nm (λex = 340 nm), respectively, with the network 1 emission being red-shifted compared to the ligand emission, independent of the excitation wavelength.

elements.content: The AIE-active fluorescence of network 1 has been used for sensing aromatic compounds bearing electron-donating or -withdrawing groups, which can quench or enhance the fluorescence of 1. To demonstrate the applicability of the networks for sensing VOCs, network 1 was activated by pumping under vacuum at 150 °C for 6 h (to remove the incorporated TCE molecules) and then soaked at room temperature in various liquid VOCs and the changes in emission measured. When compared to the initial spectrum, the VOC treated network demonstrated predictable shifts in wavelength and intensity. illustrates that treatment of network 1 with benzene and/or its methyl-substituted derivatives resulted in a change in intensity which is inversely dependent on the degree of substitution of the VOC. The expected turn-on fluorescence was observed for all of the methyl-substituted derivatives, with the magnitude of the intensity increasing with a consistent 13 nm red-shift as the degree of methyl substitution decreased. In addition to the red-shift, the quantum fluorescence yield (ΦFL) increased as compared to network 1 (ΦFL = 13.5%), for example, mesitylene exhibited a ΦFL 21%, and likewise, an increase in ΦFL was observed with decreasing methyl-substitution as in the series meta-xylene, toluene, and benzene, with ΦFL values of 29%, 36% and 43%, respectively.
elements.clean_text: The AIE-active fluorescence of network 1 has been used for sensing aromatic compounds bearing electron-donating or -withdrawing groups, which can quench or enhance the fluorescence of 1. To demonstrate the applicability of the networks for sensing VOCs, network 1 was activated by pumping under vacuum at 150 °C for 6 h (to remove the incorporated TCE molecules) and then soaked at room temperature in various liquid VOCs and the changes in emission measured. When compared to the initial spectrum, the VOC treated network demonstrated predictable shifts in wavelength and intensity.  illustrates that treatment of network 1 with benzene and/or its methyl-substituted derivatives resulted in a change in intensity which is inversely dependent on the degree of substitution of the VOC. The expected turn-on fluorescence was observed for all of the methyl-substituted derivatives, with the magnitude of the intensity increasing with a consistent 13 nm red-shift as the degree of methyl substitution decreased. In addition to the red-shift, the quantum fluorescence yield (ΦFL) increased as compared to network 1 (ΦFL = 13.5%), for example, mesitylene exhibited a ΦFL 21%, and likewise, an increase in ΦFL was observed with decreasing methyl-substitution as in the series meta-xylene, toluene, and benzene, with ΦFL values of 29%, 36% and 43%, respectively.

elements.content: Fluorescence intensity changes of 1 when exposed to methyl- and nitro-substituted VOCs.
elements.clean_text: 3  Fluorescence intensity changes of 1 when exposed to methyl- and nitro-substituted VOCs.

elements.content: The combination of consistent shift and observed turn-on fluorescence suggests that the analytes progressively lock the rotation/vibration of the central phenyl rings. The regular shift on addition of each methyl substituent suggests that they interact with the network forcing a coplanar orientation of the central rings and thus a bathochromic shift. Thus, the structure of the Zn-Py-TPE 1 network appears to strongly favor π–π interactions with VOCs.
elements.clean_text: The combination of consistent shift and observed turn-on fluorescence suggests that the analytes progressively lock the rotation/vibration of the central phenyl rings. The regular shift on addition of each methyl substituent suggests that they interact with the network forcing a coplanar orientation of the central rings and thus a bathochromic shift. Thus, the structure of the Zn-Py-TPE 1 network appears to strongly favor π-π interactions with VOCs.

elements.content: The quenching efficiency (QE) is determined by the equation QE = (I 0 – I)/I 0 where I 0 is the intensity before exposure to the analytes and I is the intensity after exposure to analytes. To demonstrate the ability of the networks to detect explosive residues, activated Zn-Py-TPE 1 was exposed to the vapors of nitrobenzene (NB) (vapor pressure at 25 °C = 0.3 mmHg = 0.0004 atm) for various time periods (1, 3, 6, 24 h) at room temperature, as shown in . This was repeated using 2,4-dinitrotoluene (DNT) (vapor pressure at 25 °C = 1 mmHg = 0.001 atm) and exposure to these analytes led to a quenching (“turn-off”) of the fluorescence () with a 13 nm hypsochromic (blue) shift of network 1 being observed (). The effect was relatively fast, and the fluorescence quenching efficiency reached its maximum after approximately 6 h exposure (84.1% for NB, 62.4% for DNT) with only limited reduction occurring on extended exposure ().
elements.clean_text: The quenching efficiency (QE) is determined by the equation QE = (I 0 - I)/I 0 where I 0 is the intensity before exposure to the analytes and I is the intensity after exposure to analytes. To demonstrate the ability of the networks to detect explosive residues, activated Zn-Py-TPE 1 was exposed to the vapors of nitrobenzene (NB) (vapor pressure at 25 °C = 0.3 mmHg = 0.0004 atm) for various time periods (1, 3, 6, 24 h) at room temperature, as shown in . This was repeated using 2,4-dinitrotoluene (DNT) (vapor pressure at 25 °C = 1 mmHg = 0.001 atm) and exposure to these analytes led to a quenching ("turn-off") of the fluorescence () with a 13 nm hypsochromic (blue) shift of network 1 being observed (). The effect was relatively fast, and the fluorescence quenching efficiency reached its maximum after approximately 6 h exposure (84.1% for NB, 62.4% for DNT) with only limited reduction occurring on extended exposure ().

elements.content: Fluorescence intensity changes of 1 when exposed to nitrobenzene at different time intervals.
elements.clean_text: 4  Fluorescence intensity changes of 1 when exposed to nitrobenzene at different time intervals.

elements.content: Importantly for both type of analytes, the response was fully reversible and the network 1 could be readily regenerated by simply pumping off the absorbed analyte at 150 °C for 3 h. The reversibility of the network was demonstrated by the absence of a reduction in the evacuated networks fluorescence as well as a consistent response after three evacuation cycles (see Supporting Information Figure 13). To confirm full evacuation of the pores and the stability of the network, a sample soaked with toluene was analyzed via thermogravimetric (TGA) analysis and the exhaust gases analyzed via GC–MS and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR). The TGA result was similar to that of the synthesized network, but with a smaller (15%) weight loss, as expected, given the lower molar mass of toluene as compared to TCE. GC–MS and FTIR confirmed that the species lost during heating was toluene (see Supporting Information Figure S8–11).
elements.clean_text: Importantly for both type of analytes, the response was fully reversible and the network 1 could be readily regenerated by simply pumping off the absorbed analyte at 150 °C for 3 h. The reversibility of the network was demonstrated by the absence of a reduction in the evacuated networks fluorescence as well as a consistent response after three evacuation cycles (see Supporting Information Figure 13). To confirm full evacuation of the pores and the stability of the network, a sample soaked with toluene was analyzed via thermogravimetric (TGA) analysis and the exhaust gases analyzed via GC-MS and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR). The TGA result was similar to that of the synthesized network, but with a smaller (15%) weight loss, as expected, given the lower molar mass of toluene as compared to TCE. GC-MS and FTIR confirmed that the species lost during heating was toluene (see Supporting Information Figure S8-11).

elements.content: The sensing behavior of network 1 can be attributed to the highly porous network structure and the intensely fluorescent nature of the ligand. The increase in dimensionality of a network has been shown to improve sensitivity because excitons can be quenched through energy migration in the solid state. The highly conjugated nature of the network may encourage this behavior. High porosity is clearly desirable in sensor materials since it allows ready access to binding sites and easy diffusion through the bulk material, so enhancing both response time and intensity changes. The large pores (13.4 × 17.5 Å) and easily accessible binding sites of 1 demonstrate the importance of these effects. The binding sites consist of phenyl and pyridine rings that are capable of rotation/vibration. The analyte enters the pore and hinders these actions by blocking nonradiative decay and inducing the turn-on fluorescence. This mechanism is distinct from other fluorescent MOFs. The differing response of the methyl-substituted aromatic VOCs versus the nitro-substituted aromatics demonstrates the potential of this material to act as a selective and sensitive sensor, and may arise from the difference in low polarity of methyl-substituents compared to the polar nitro-substituents. The selectivity of this network is highly dependent on the predictability of the peak shift. The mechanism of analyte interaction, dependent on the substituent, suggests that the binding amount per host would also be distinct for VOCs; the nitro-phenyl substituted VOCs likely having different binding modes than the methyl-aromatic VOCs. It is difficult to judge specific binding affinity as encapsulation and release of VOCs was performed in the solid state. The fluorescent shift seen in this work assumes saturation of binding sites as each sample was given sufficient time to reach an equilibrium state, while the observed fluorescence change is specific to the particular VOC, and also to the nature and completeness of its binding to the substrate, among other factors.

The increase in dimensionality of a network has been shown to improve sensitivity because excitons can be quenched through energy migration in the solid state. The highly conjugated nature of the network may encourage this behavior. High porosity is clearly desirable in sensor materials since it allows ready access to binding sites and easy diffusion through the bulk material, so enhancing both response time and intensity changes. The large pores (13.4 × 17.5 Å) and easily accessible binding sites of 1 demonstrate the importance of these effects. The binding sites consist of phenyl and pyridine rings that are capable of rotation/vibration. The analyte enters the pore and hinders these actions by blocking nonradiative decay and inducing the turn-on fluorescence. This mechanism is distinct from other fluorescent MOFs. The differing response of the methyl-substituted aromatic VOCs versus the nitro-substituted aromatics demonstrates the potential of this material to act as a selective and sensitive sensor, and may arise from the difference in low polarity of methyl-substituents compared to the polar nitro-substituents. The selectivity of this network is highly dependent on the predictability of the peak shift. The mechanism of analyte interaction, dependent on the substituent, suggests that the binding amount per host would also be distinct for VOCs; the nitro-phenyl substituted VOCs likely having different binding modes than the methyl-aromatic VOCs. It is difficult to judge specific binding affinity as encapsulation and release of VOCs was performed in the solid state. The fluorescent shift seen in this work assumes saturation of binding sites as each sample was given sufficient time to reach an equilibrium state, while the observed fluorescence change is specific to the particular VOC, and also to the nature and completeness of its binding to the substrate, among other factors.

elements.content: In summary, by careful choice of ligand and crystal engineering, a novel network that retains the AIE fluorescence of the ligand, in the as-synthesized form and in the evacuated/activated form, has been constructed. The network consists of a central TPE and four pyridine rings coordinating to zinc chloride centers in an infinite ribbon chain. This leaves four phenyl and four pyridine rings that can freely rotate and vibrate, which results in multiple enhancement, or quenching sites, decorating the large channels of the structure. These sites, and the behavior of the ligand, demonstrate selective responses to different analytes. Thus, the network is able to detect various VOCs and differentiate between them (via either a turn-on or a turn-off interaction). The network also demonstrates a selective response toward explosive vapor residues in an acceptable time frame. This work reinforces the potential of MOFs to detect explosive residues and suggests the potential for further applications in sensing.
elements.clean_text: In summary, by careful choice of ligand and crystal engineering, a novel network that retains the AIE fluorescence of the ligand, in the as-synthesized form and in the evacuated/activated form, has been constructed. The network consists of a central TPE and four pyridine rings coordinating to zinc chloride centers in an infinite ribbon chain. This leaves four phenyl and four pyridine rings that can freely rotate and vibrate, which results in multiple enhancement, or quenching sites, decorating the large channels of the structure. These sites, and the behavior of the ligand, demonstrate selective responses to different analytes. Thus, the network is able to detect various VOCs and differentiate between them (via either a turn-on or a turn-off interaction). The network also demonstrates a selective response toward explosive vapor residues in an acceptable time frame. This work reinforces the potential of MOFs to detect explosive residues and suggests the potential for further applications in sensing.

cln_elements.clean_text: The ligand Py-TPE (10 mg, 0.0156 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of 3:1 tetrachloroethene (TCE)/methanol, which then had a methanolic solution of zinc chloride (10 mL, 8.7 mg, 0.64 mmol) layered on top. Upon standing for several days, yellow plate-like crystals of (Zn2Cl4Py-TPE)⋅4(TCE) (1) (69% yield) formed, which were characterized by elemental analysis: Calcd for (Zn2Cl4Py-TPE) after removal of solvent is C, 60.49; N, 6.17%; H, 3.53. Found C, 60.78; N, 6.14; H, 3.59%. Its thermal stability was examined by thermogravimetric (TGA) analysis and its structure determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis.

other properties: structure determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction

intermediate_step.text-synthesis-struct:
```JSON
[{"meta":{"name":"(Zn2Cl4Py-TPE)⋅4(TCE)", "symbol":"1", "chemical formula":"C60H42Cl4N4Zn2"}, "processes":[{"synthesis method":"chemical synthesis", "precursor":[{"name":"Py-TPE", "amount":"10", "unit":"mg"}, {"name":"zinc chloride", "amount":"8.7", "unit":"mg"}], "solution":[{"name":"TCE/methanol", "amount":"15", "unit":"mL"}, {"name":"methanolic solution of zinc chloride", "amount":"10", "unit":"mL"}], "pressure":"", "temperature":"", "time":"several days"}], "yield":"69%", "other properties":["thermal stability examined by TGA", "structure determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction"]}]
```

cln_elements.content: In contrast to the free Py-TPE ligand, which decomposes at temperatures above 120 °C, compound 1 demonstrated thermal stability up to 450 °C. The TGA performed in an inert atmosphere (N2) shows two distinct losses. First, at 150 °C, there is a 40% weight-loss that corresponds to TCE expulsion beyond which the network remains stable until 450 °C, after which it begins to decay and evolve organic decomposition products. Upon completion of the TGA at 750 °C, 35% of the mass remains, which can be attributed to the remaining metal oxide and decomposition products. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis demonstrated the resilience of the structure since even after five regeneration cycles (150 °C under vacuum for 3 h), the PXRD remained unchanged (see Supporting Information Figure S6). b,c shows the creation of rhomboid shaped voids (13.4 × 17.5 Å) within the structure, which are occupied by TCE molecules that have been incorporated during the synthesis. This was confirmed via GC–MS and FTIR analysis of the volatiles released during the TGA after the loss of 10% of the total mass. Additionally, the evacuated network was analyzed via TGA. It demonstrated the expected behavior; remaining stable until the pyrolysis of the ligand at 500 °C (see Supporting Information Figure S12).
cln_elements.clean_text: In contrast to the free Py-TPE ligand, which decomposes at temperatures above 120 °C, compound 1 demonstrated thermal stability up to 450 °C. The TGA performed in an inert atmosphere (N2) shows two distinct losses. First, at 150 °C, there is a 40% weight-loss that corresponds to TCE expulsion beyond which the network remains stable until 450 °C, after which it begins to decay and evolve organic decomposition products. Upon completion of the TGA at 750 °C, 35% of the mass remains, which can be attributed to the remaining metal oxide and decomposition products. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis demonstrated the resilience of the structure since even after five regeneration cycles (150 °C under vacuum for 3 h), the PXRD remained unchanged (see Supporting Information Figure S6). b,c shows the creation of rhomboid shaped voids (13.4 × 17.5 Å) within the structure, which are occupied by TCE molecules that have been incorporated during the synthesis. This was confirmed via GC-MS and FTIR analysis of the volatiles released during the TGA after the loss of 10% of the total mass. Additionally, the evacuated network was analyzed via TGA. It demonstrated the expected behavior; remaining stable until the pyrolysis of the ligand at 500 °C (see Supporting Information Figure S12).

decomposition temperature.condition: remaining metal oxide and decomposition products

Details of Crystal Data and Structure Refinement Parameters of [(ZnCl<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub> Py-TPE] <bold>1</bold> <xref rid="tbl1-fn1"></xref> empirical formula C31H24Cl2ZnN2 Mr 560.79 crystal size 0.067 × 0.085 × 0.210 crystal color clear yellow crystal system monoclinic space group C2/m T (K) 200(1) a (Å) 18.902(3) b (Å) 17.472(3) c (Å) 13.206(2) α (deg) 90 β (deg) 115.736(3) γ (deg) 90 volume (Å3) 3928.7(10) Z 4 D calc (g cm–3) 0.948 μ (mm–1) 0.777 2θmax (deg) 52.88 data collected 21554 refined parameters/restraints 4154/170 goodness of fit on F 2 0.877 R1 [I > 2σ(I)] 0.0529 wR2 (all data) 0.1566

Note that the occluded TCE molecules were masked using SQUEEZE and so are not represented in this table (CCDC: 1458042).

cln_elements.content: Structure of tetrapyridine-tetraphenylethene (Py-TPE) ligand.
(a) Asymmetric unit of 1. (b) Pores viewed along the a axis. (c) One-dimensional infinite chain of 1. (d) Packing between the chains.
